resource.name: Supply Chain Shipment Pricing Dataset
resource.description: This dataset provides supply chain health commodity shipment and pricing data. Specifically, the data set identifies Antiretroviral (ARV) and HIV lab shipments to supported countries. In addition, the data set provides the commodity pricing and associated supply chain expenses necessary to move the commodities to countries for use. The dataset has similar fields to the Global Fund's Price, Quality and Reporting (PQR) data. PEPFAR and the Global Fund represent the two largest procurers of HIV health commodities. This dataset, when analyzed in conjunction with the PQR data, provides a more complete picture of global spending on specific health commodities. The data are particularly valuable for understanding ranges and trends in pricing as well as volumes delivered by country. The US Government believes this data will help stakeholders make better, data-driven decisions. Care should be taken to consider contextual factors when using the database. Conclusions related to costs associated with moving specific line items or products to specific countries and lead times by product/country will not be accurate.

resource.name: USAID Anticorruption Projects Database
resource.description: The Anticorruption Projects Database (Database) includes information about USAID projects with anticorruption interventions implemented worldwide between 2007 and 2013. The Database includes about 300 long-term country projects and regional or short-term projects. Projects were identified and information collected by the six Implementing Partners (IP) of the ENGAGE Indefinite Quantity Contract. Criteria for selecting projects included: distinctive project interventions targeted at reducing corruption or promoting government integrity, accountability and transparency that ultimately results in reducing opportunities to corruption. Availability of sufficient information about the projects was another criterion for selecting them to the Database. This included but was not limited to project description and results, implementation timeframe, project value, and implementer. After reviewing approximately 2000 projects, more than 300 were identified for the Database.

resource.name: Development Credit Authority (DCA) Data Set: Loan Transactions
resource.description: USAID's Development Credit Authority (DCA) works with investors, local financial institutions, and development organizations to design and deliver investment alternatives that unlock financing for U.S. Government priorities. USAID guarantees encourage private lenders to extend financing to underserved borrowers in new sectors and regions. This dataset is the complete list of all private loans made under USAID's DCA since it was established in 1999. To protect the personal information of borrowers and bank partners, all strategic and personal identifiable information was removed.

resource.name: Nepal Business Literacy Impact Evaluation - Baseline Household-Member Dataset
resource.description:
Feed the Future activities in Nepal include the Business Literacy (BL) Program, which operates in conjunction with the Knowledge-Based Integrated Sustainable Agriculture and Nutrition (KISAN) Project. Nepal Business Literacy (BL) Impact Evaluation (IE) is designed to collect and analyze three rounds of qualitative and quantitative data collected in order to learn from evidence of the extent to which initial and persistent results of the BL training course occur. The Nepal BL IE is designed to investigate initial and longer-term or persistent impacts of the training experience on targeted aspects of beneficiaries’ knowledge, skills, attitudes (KSA), and behaviors. Investigators also are interested in whether and to what extent the BL training experience leads to adoption of targeted behaviors, such as starting new micro enterprises, that persist over time.

This dataset (n=11,760, vars=25) is the household roster for the 2016 Nepal IE Baseline Survey. It has one record per household member listed in Module C. The unique identifiers for this file are pbs_id + hm_id (household member id). Derived variables (e.g., age group, “agegrp15+”) are also included in this dataset.

resource.name: A genome‑wide association and meta‑analysis: Genome-wide association study (GWAS) results
resource.description: Seed size is an important trait for yield and commercial value in dry-grain cowpea. Seed size varies widely among different cowpea accessions, and the genetic basis of such variation is not yet well understood. To better decipher the genetic basis of seed size, a genome-wide association study (GWAS) and meta-analysis were conducted on a panel of 368 cowpea diverse accessions from 51 countries. Four traits, including seed weight, length, width and density were evaluated across three locations. Using 51,128 single nucleotide polymorphisms covering the cowpea genome, 17 loci were identified for these traits. One locus was common to weight, width and length, suggesting pleiotropy. By integrating synteny-based analysis with common bean, six candidate genes (Vigun05g036000, Vigun05g039600, Vigun05g204200, Vigun08g217000, Vigun11g187000, and Vigun11g191300) which are implicated in multiple functional categories related to seed size such as endosperm development, embryo development, and cell elongation were identified. These results suggest that a combination of GWAS meta-analysis with synteny comparison in a related plant is an efficient approach to identify candidate gene (s) for complex traits in cowpea. The identified loci and candidate genes provide useful information for improving cowpea varieties and for molecular investigation of seed size.

domain_metadata.value: Sassoum Lo, María Muñoz‑Amatriaín, Samuel A. Hokin, Ndiaga Cisse, Philip A. Roberts, Andrew D. Farmer, Shizhong Xu, Timothy J. Close. 2023. A genome‑wide association and meta‑analysis: Genome-wide association study (GWAS) results. Dataset. USAID Development Data Library. https://data.usaid.gov/d/wmek-4p42.
Sassoum Lo, María Muñoz‑Amatriaín, Samuel A. Hokin, Ndiaga Cisse, Philip A. Roberts, Andrew D. Farmer, Shizhong Xu, Timothy J. Close
Bureau for Resilience and Food Security
There is no potentially sensitive data within this data asset.

The data and metadata that comprise this open access, peer-reviewed technical publication provide guidance on genetic variability related to seed size in cowpea. Seed size is an important aspect of consumer preferences, thus also an important aspect of the development of new cowpea varieties through breeding. The information in this publication describes reliable genetic markers to track genetic variants for seed size in parents and progeny.

resource.name: Feed the Future Northern Kenya Zone of Influence Survey Baseline - Food Consumption Dataset
resource.description:
Feed the Future seeks to reduce poverty and undernutrition in 19 developing countries including Kenya by focusing on accelerating growth of the agricultural sector, addressing root causes of undernutrition, and reducing gender inequality.

This dataset (n=243,789, vars=28) contains variables from Module E1, Food Consumption Over Past 7 Days. Each household with food consumption data has multiple records (for the 133 food items in sub-Module E1). (243,789 records divided by 133 food items =1,833 Module E households with sub-Module E1 data.).

domain_metadata.value: Westat. 2023. Feed the Future Northern Kenya Zone of Influence Survey Baseline - Food Consumption Dataset. Dataset. USAID Development Data Library. https://data.usaid.gov/d/wp3g-2r2g.

All survey specific data elements should be removed as they are only useful in managing the implementation of the survey: date of interview, ability to be interviewed alone, outcome of the interview.

A range of household level data elements were reported in all other datasets and should be removed from all datasets except household’s. Examples include dwelling characteristics (roof, floor, walls) and hunger scale questions.

We will use the following steps to anonymize the datasets:
1.	Use k-anonymity to mitigate the following variables: sex, dwelling characteristics, relationship to household head, type of toilets, education level, literacy level (read and write), district, urbanization. To achieve a threshold of k=3, we will recode some of these variables including dwelling characteristics, type of toilets, relationship to household head, education level, and literacy level  
2.	Aggregate age variable into 5 ages bands. 
3.	Apply a micro aggregation to children and women weights and heights. Micro Aggregation replaces each single value with local means calculated on batches of 3 records each. 
4.	Top code the age and estimated price of house. Any reported house age value above 100 years was recoded as 100; any estimated price at 5 000 000 or above was replaced with the mean price of houses costing 5 000 000 or more. 
5.	      5. Capping household size to 13. To achieve this, we will randomly select out of the datasets individual members from these large households who do not participate anywhere else in the survey other than their membership to household. Initially, the largest household had 21 members; after this process, this household would have 13 members. The median household in Kenya is about 4.4. In this data, the median remains at 5.0 before and after households disclosure risk mitigation.

Most of the data elements identified as indirect identifiers in this data asset represent valuable background information about the study question including subjects’ demographics as well as other general characteristics related to the study. Removing these data elements will negatively impact the utility of the data. The following elements should be retained in the data: sex, age, weight, height, district, education, and dwelling characteristics. The following data elements should be removed: date of birth and village.

domain_metadata.value: PREDICT Consortium. 2020. PREDICT Event Animal Production (China). Dataset. USAID Development Data Library. https://data.usaid.gov/d/wqu9-tdt4.
The embargo is requested pending approval of publications by the appropriate government authorities in China.

All GPS locations are rounded to 2 decimal places (accuracy of about 1 km) to protect sensitive sampling sites related to wildlife. Direct and indirect identifiers have been removed from human data using HIPAA Privacy Rule guidance and human data are aggregated and summarized to further protect individuals sampled.

This data includes both a wide range of variables and rare and unique variables related to known and novel viruses, including where and in what species they were found. Data were collected in Africa and Asia in communities with high-risk wildlife contact and includes variables that can inform on risk associated with zoonotic pathogen transmission and potential targets for intervention to minimize risk of pathogen spillover.

resource.name: Feed the Future Malawi Interim Survey in the Zone of Infuence, Durable Goods Expenditures
resource.description: This dataset contains data from sub-Module E7: Durable Goods Expenditures. It is part of the 2015 Feed the Future Malawi Interim Survey in the Zone of Influence. The survey was designed to monitor program performance by periodic assessments of a number of standardized indicators.  A total of 1,021 households were interviewed, which provided data for the target sample size of 1,007 households and ensured the sample is representative of the seven districts covered in the interim assessment.  Each household with data for durable goods expenditures has multiple records (for the 31 durable goods in sub-Module E7). (31,651 records ÷ 31 non-food items = 1,021 Module E households with sub-Module E7 data.) The unique identifiers in this long file are pbs_id + e701.

One simple change in the excel file could make the code full of bugs.

resource.name: Agricultural Land Dynamics and Land Policy in Rural Tanzania 2016: Crop Price Dataset
resource.description:
This table contains conversions for crop prices. The table can be combined with other datasets in this data asset using the 'crop' column.

The purpose of collecting these data was to examine farm expansion and labor markets in rural Tanzania. Data were collected in 8 rural districts of Tanzania: Mvomero, Kilombero, Njombe, Kiteto, Magu, Moshi Rural, Mkuranga and Liwale.

The data were collected through the Feed the Future Innovation Lab for Food Security Policy (FSP).

domain_metadata.value: Margaret Beaver. 2019. Agricultural Land Dynamics and Land Policy in Rural Tanzania 2016: Crop Price Dataset. Dataset. USAID Development Data Library. https://data.usaid.gov/d/wsw2-mw7s.
See the word document "2016_ALDSDataFileNotes.doc" for details on specific variables that may have data issues. Some plot areas were not allocated by crop but given as total area (see notes)

Examine the rate of land expansion of medium- and large-scale farms compared
to small scale farms, look at policy implications of consequent changes in
farm structure and the concentration of food production and marketed output;
Examine the pace of acquisition of agricultural land by medium- and
large-scale investors through de facto land administration policies; examine
the implication of such dynamics on rural youth land accessibility and out
migration in the context of customary tenure systems; assess the broader
effects of changing farm structure on the types of pace of non-farm
employment growth; understand the relationship between farm size and
efficiency, including the range of factors and policies that might condition
this relationship and specifically examine the impacts of large commercial
agricultural operations on the welfare of rural communities around them.
Examine the extent of land disputes and conflicts in rural Tanzania, their
causes, possible resolution mechanisms, and policy implications to land
investments in Tanzania as well as the implications of the formal and
informal land tenure systems in shaping incidence and intensity of land
dynamics.

resource.name: Feed the Future Malawi: Baseline Household Survey, Household Members
resource.description: This dataset describes the members of the households that participated in this baseline survey.  The spreadsheet has 33 columns and 15,027 rows.  The Malawi Population-Based Survey (PBS) provides a comprehensive assessment of the current status of agriculture and food security in seven districts in the Central and Southern Regions: Mchinji, Lilongwe, Dedza, Ntcheu, Balaka, Machinga, and Mangochi.  The PBS was conducted from November 14 to December 22, 2012.  The overall objective of the survey is to provide baseline on data living standards, nutritional status, and women's empowerment in agriculture in the Zone Of Influence.  A total of 3,397 households in the ZOI were interviewed for the PBS, and these households were spread across 126 rural standard enumeration areas (SEAs) in the seven districts.

resource.name: Section P1 Livestock Assets
resource.description: The survey interviewed 254 retailer shops in 10 sub-cities of Addis Ababa. 30 supermarkets, 20 mini-markets, 100 regular shops, 80 dairy shops and 24 open market shops selling dairy products were interviewed. Details of the sampling strategy is found in the attachment. The survey collected information on the characteristics of the shop, details of dairy products sold, prices and quality. Policy makers, research, and other stakeholders can use this data to analyses dairy value chain in Ethiopia and dairy retailing practices in Ethiopia. This data set was collected through research of the project “Improving the evidence and policies for better performing livestock systems in Ethiopia” lead by the International Food Policy Research Institution as part of the Feed the Future Innovation Lab for Livestock Systems.

resource.name: Indonesia LESTARI Greenhouse Gas Emission Reduction: Land Cover 2018-2019
resource.description: This data has land use information for Aceh in 2018 and for Katingan-Kahayan, Lorentz Lowlands, Mappi-Bouven Digoel, Sarmi and Cyclops landscapes in 2019. In 2019, land use classes were simplified to speed up the process and focus on forest change only. Land use changes and emissions of non-forests are not required under the FREL method.

domain_tags: land use change; ghg emissions; frel

domain_metadata.value: Tetra Tech ARD. 2021. Indonesia LESTARI Greenhouse Gas Emission Reduction: Land Cover 2018-2019. Dataset. USAID Development Data Library. https://data.usaid.gov/d/wzh2-pyif.
Bureau for Development, Democracy, and Innovation

This data allows the user to understand where landscape deforestation and degradation has occurred in 6 key Indonesian landscapes from 2015 - 2019 and calculate the resulting GHG emissions. USAID LESTARI produced 2019 land use data for all landscapes in-house as official data had not been published at the end of the project. Data for 2018 in the Aceh landscape is also available as this was produced by the project. These datasets were produced using the FREL methodology.

resource.name: Feed the Future Northern Kenya Interim Survey in the Zone of Influence, Household Consumption Expenditures
resource.description: Feed the Future Northern Kenya Interim Survey in the Zone of Influence: This dataset (n=1,837, vars=66) contains variables from Module E, the Household Consumption Expenditures module used to calculate the poverty and expenditure indicators. It includes household-level derived variables (including the expenditure and poverty indicator variables), as well as variables from sub-module E6:Housing Expenditures.
columns_description: These data were collected in the 2015 Interim Zone of Influence Survey.
Cluster number
Derived daily rent for aggregation

Consumption shortfall of the poor at the national extreme (food) poverty threshold. Value is normalized to the poverty threshold and households, such that values are expressed as a proportion of the poverty line, with consumption at the threshold or higher are set to missing.

Consumption shortfall of the poor at the national poverty threshold. Value is normalized to the poverty threshold and households, such that values are expressed as a proportion of the poverty line, with consumption at the threshold or higher are set to missing.

Poverty gap at the national poverty threshold. Value is normalized to the poverty threshold, such that values are expressed as a proportion of the poverty line, and households with consumption at the threshold or higher are set to missing.

Poverty gap at the poverty threshold of less than 1.25 per person per day in 2005 PPP. Value is normalized to the poverty threshold, such that values are expressed as a proportion of the poverty line, and households with consumption at the threshold or higher are set to missing.
Daily per capita consumption in Kenya shillings, 2005 prices

The extreme poverty threshold is the poverty line established by the Kenya Integrated Household Budget Survey -2005 06. This value is 1,562 2,913 (rural urban) Kenya shillings per month per adult equivalent. This threshold has been adjusted to reflect a daily per capita threshold. This threshold, when adjusted to daily per capita terms can be different across households.

Derived daily total HH expenditures in Kenya shillings, 2005 prices. This total does not include the household s financial transfers (e.g., donations, taxes, loans) or large ceremonial expenses. These types of expenses are conventionally excluded because they insert bias into poverty estimates.
Total daily household expenditure on health care, Kenyan shillings in 2005 prices. Educational expenses include costs such as school uniforms, school supplies, tuition, or other fees.

Total daily household expenditure on health care, Kenyan shillings in 2005 prices. This include expenses incurred to obtain medical treatment for illnesses or preventative health care. Health care may be provided for formal medical providers or traditional practitioners. The major health care expenses and hospitalizations that are reported in Module E5 are not included in this measure because these introduce considerable bias into poverty estimates.

Total daily household expenditure on recreational and leisure, Kenyan shillings in 2005 prices. This includes cell phones and costs related to the use of a cell phone, land line phone services, mail or courier fees.

Total daily household expenditure on recreational and leisure, Kenyan shillings in 2005 prices. This includes durable goods used for entertainment, discretionary items used for enjoyment, and leisure travel.
Total daily household consumption on household furnishings, Kenyan shillings in 2005 prices. These are durable or semipermanent objects that are used to supply a home.

Total daily household consumption on household maintenance and upkeep, Kenyan shillings in 2005 prices. This includes water and electric utilities, as well as he costs associated with purchasing or obtaining access to energy (such as electricity, gas, or firewood) and water. This also includes the reported household s reported costs associated with household reports as reported in Module E6.

Total daily household consumption of food items (excluding alcohol), Kenyan shillings in 2005 prices with a spatial price adjustment using a Paashe index. The adjusted value in this variable is included in interim assessment analyses.
Total daily household consumption of food items (excluding alcohol), Kenyan shillings in 2005 prices.
This variable is the person weight used to the weight the data to produce population-level poverty estimates.

This measure is calculated from a hedonic regression of rental values reported by renters. Housing rental values were then predicted for non-renters by using the model coefficients and dwelling characteristics of non-renters.

resource.name: Feed the Future Uganda Life of Activity Farmer Data: Year 1 Survey (April to September 2014)
resource.description: Life of activity farmer data (collected through Form 6 between October 2014 and September 2017) for the Feed the Future Uganda Commodity Production and Marketing Activity. This data was collected from farmers who have been reached through CPM-related interventions and broadly speaking, captures changes in adoption of CPM-promoted practices and the resulting impacts on production (i.e. improved quality and increased quantities produced). Moreover, Form 6 data supports reporting for nine Feed the Future indicators. In addition to the datasets, supporting documents include Form 6 survey tools used for each survey and calculation guides for computing the nine Feed the Future indicators that Form 6 measures.

domain_metadata.value: Chemonics International, Inc.. 2020. Feed the Future Uganda Life of Activity Farmer Data: Year 1 Survey (April to September 2014). Dataset. USAID Development Data Library. https://data.usaid.gov/d/x992-dkb2.

The data was originally stripped of most PII at time of submission, including demographic
information of respondents (except the date of interview), GPS coordinates, and village information in some datasets. All of these PII have been removed as they provide no or limited usefulness to the data.

Agriculture is one of the most important components of the Ugandan economy, with 14 percent of gross domestic product, 85 percent of total export earning, and 73 percent of total employment. The Feed the Future intervention invested in increasing the production of maize, beans, and coffee through the appropriate use of high-quality agricultural inputs and decreasing the prevalence of counterfeit agricultural inputs, like mislabeled seeds or diluted fertilizers, in the market. It relied on an innovative market facilitation approach that empowers local actors such as the “Village Agent” to serve as role models in the agriculture industry and act as champions of best practices for the
way agricultural inputs are bought and sold.

resource.name: Community Resilience Activity (CRA) Safe Charity Assessment: Phase 1 Business Data
resource.description:
The United States Agency for International Development (USAID)/Pakistan-funded Safe Charity campaign seeks to reduce financial support to violent extremist groups by educating those who give charity about how to direct their charity to safe recipients in Multan and Karachi. In Multan, the campaign trained influential farmers to disseminate safe charity messages to other farmers; and chambers of commerce and industry, trade and marketing associations, and the Rotary Club to reach the business community. In Karachi, the campaign engaged community youth centers to disseminate messages. The campaign timed its activities to align with common periods of charitable giving, namely Ramazan, Eid ul-Fitr, and Eid ul-Azha. 

These surveys established a baseline of current knowledge and practices with respect to safe charity in Multan and Karachi during each giving period and identified changes in knowledge and practices that could be plausibly linked to the safe charity campaign.

domain_tags: institute of social and policy sciences

domain_metadata.value: Management Systems International (MSI). 2020. Community Resilience Activity (CRA) Safe Charity Assessment: Phase 1 Business Data. Dataset. USAID Development Data Library. https://data.usaid.gov/d/xcyw-a2zr.

The assessment conducted structured surveys of farmer and business communities in Multan and of participants of community youth center activities in Karachi. The assessment team collected survey data in two phases, each phase aligning with one of two selected periods of charitable and corresponding safe charity activities. Phase I aligned with activities relating to charitable giving during Ramazan and Eid ul-Fitr and collected data on decision-making patterns, knowledge, attitudes, and behavior with respect to the giving of zakat and fitrana during that period. Phase II aligned with activities relating to charitable giving during Eid ul-Azha and collected data on similar topics with respect to the giving of animal hides. The Phase II sample consisted primarily of individuals who had also participated in the Phase I survey. The primary limitation to the data from the Phase I survey was a snowball sampling approach to identifying survey respondents who had been exposed to safe charity messaging. For example, the survey team relied on farmer leaders, who had directly engaged with the safe charity campaign, to identify other members of farmer communities with knowledge of safe charity activities. While it was necessary to include “secondary” farmers in the survey sample to assess the reach of safe charity messaging within target communities, the survey team could not guarantee that secondary farmers had participated in safe charity activities or been exposed to safe charity messaging. Furthermore, there is a high likelihood of a selection bias in farmer leader referrals. To control for this bias, the survey team identified enough secondary farmers to create a secondary sampling frame, from which respondents could be randomly selected. The primary limitation to the survey of members of the business community was lack of familiarity with the safe charity campaign, particularly among corporate businesses. This may have been due to challenges identifying knowledgeable individuals within corporate businesses, lower levels of engagement between corporate businesses and their respective chambers of commerce, or characteristics of the corporate engagement strategy of the safe charity campaign.  Whereas the Phase I surveys focused on the giving of zakat and fitrana, the Phase II survey focused specifically on safe charity practices for the giving of qurbani. Phase II included only farmers and excluded the business community and Karachi youth center participants. The survey team employed a longitudinal design, surveying the same farmers who participated in Phase I. By surveying the same respondents, the assessment team examined layered (or repeated) exposure to safe charity activities and compared perceptions around different types of giving. However, given the unique circumstances and distinct forms of charity common to each charitable giving period, differences in behavior between Phase I and II should not be construed as change in behavior attributable to the safe charity campaign.

All unique individual identifiers, including names, addresses, and phone numbers of respondents, as well as names of data collection and processing teams, have been removed from the CRA Safe Charity study dataset and omitted from the final report. A unique identification code has been assigned to each survey respondent, reflecting the respondent’s geographic location (city), type of respondent (direct/indirect, farmers/businessman/workshop participants) and sex. The dataset does include information pertaining to respondents’ sex, educational attainment, religion, employment status, and income, which are important variables to explain variation in responses. These variables, however, together do not provide sufficient information to identify individual respondents.

The assessment team, led by MSI and the Institute of Social and Policy Sciences (I-SAPS), conducted structured surveys of farmer and business communities in Multan and of participants of community youth center activities in Karachi. The assessment team collected survey data in two phases, each phase aligning with one of two selected periods of charitable and corresponding safe charity activities. Phase I, which took place in August 2018, aligned with activities relating to charitable giving during Ramazan and Eid ul-Fitr and collected data on decision-making patterns, knowledge, attitudes, and behavior with respect to the giving of zakat and fitrana during that period. Phase II, which took place in October 2018, aligned with activities relating to charitable giving during Eid ul-Azha and collected data on similar topics with respect to the giving of animal hides. The Phase II sample consisted primarily of individuals who had also participated in the Phase I survey. Phase I included three surveys, each targeting a unique respondent group. In Multan, the assessment team selected a random sample of 124 farmer “leaders” from 500 farmers in 11 union councils who were directly engaged by the safe charity campaign. Farmer leaders were pre-identified influential members of their communities, tasked with disseminating information to other farmers and community members through community gatherings, sensitization sessions, and other activities and events. The sample of farmer leaders was stratified by gender and union council. With assistance from farmer leaders, the assessment team then used a snowball approach to identify a sampling frame of at least 500 “secondary” farmers, or members of target communities who participated in community gatherings, sensitizations sessions, and other activities and events sponsored by the safe charity campaign. Using this sampling frame, the assessment team selected a random sample of 150 secondary farmers, also stratified by gender and union council. The assessment team conducted a second Phase I survey of members of chambers of commerce and industry in Multan. The team randomly selected 150 businesses—120 members (40 corporate members and 80 associate members) of the Multan Chamber of Commerce and Industry (MCCI), whose total membership in Multan was approximately 1,000 businesses at the time of the survey; and 30 businesses from the Women Chamber of Commerce and Industry Multan (WCCIM), whose total membership in Multan was approximately 140 businesses at the time of the survey. The assessment team conducted a third Phase I survey of all 103 participants of safe charity poster workshops conducted at Azm-e-Naujawan (AeN) community youth centers. The campaign expected another 850 community members to attend AeN safe charity poster exhibits. Through AeN center staff and poster workshop participants, the assessment team used a snowball approach to identify a sampling frame of approximately 400 visitors to the poster exhibitions. From this sampling frame, the assessment team selected a random sample of 121 exhibit visitors, stratified by gender. As with secondary farmers, the snowball approach to identifying secondary participants could not ensure activity participation or exposure to safe charity messaging, and may have been subject to a selection bias. The Phase II survey focused solely on farmer leaders and secondary farmers in Multan. During Phase II, the assessment team surveyed 124 farmer leaders, 112 of whom were surveyed in Phase I and 12 of whom were new respondents who replaced farmers that could not be reached or who were unable to participate. Similarly, the assessment team surveyed 152 secondary farmers, 131 of whom were also surveyed in Phase 1, and 21 of whom were new respondents who replaced farmers that could not be reached or who were unable to participate. Together, these surveys provide a comprehensive snapshot of how people in these communities give charity and the role that the risk of giving to violent extremist groups plays in charitable decision-making. The surveys captured three types of information. First, they probed how people give charity, including frequency of giving, type of giving, who in the household makes charitable giving decisions, why people give charity, and factors determining to whom people give charity. Second, the surveys probed people’s knowledge of the risk of giving to violent extremist groups, where people obtain information about safe charity, and how this knowledge affects decision-making. Third, the surveys probed participation in safe charity activities and the effect of this participation on knowledge and behaviors, including further dissemination of safe charity messaging. The survey data can be disaggregated by gender, age, income, religion, and respondent type, as well as period of charitable giving. The two phases of data collection provide important insights into how hyperlocal conditions of place and time affect charitable decision-making and knowledge and practice of safe charity. The survey team employed a longitudinal design, surveying the same farmers who participated in Phase I. By surveying the same respondents, the assessment team examined layered (or repeated) exposure to safe charity activities and compared perceptions around different types of giving. However, given the unique circumstances and distinct forms of charity common to each charitable giving period, differences in behavior between Phase I and II should not be construed as change in behavior attributable to the safe charity campaign. The surveys are supplemented by in-depth individual and group interviews with primary and secondary safe charity participants.

resource.name: The genome of cowpea (Vigna unguiculata [L.] Walp.): Cowpea Chromosome Polynomial Formulae
resource.description: Polynomial formulae for each cowpea chromosome. The valid range of the polynomial is indicated by the start and end positions in columns B and C, the order of the best fit (from 7th to 11th) in column D, the full formula in column E, and the constants at three significant digits in columns F through Q.

domain_metadata.value: Stefano Lonardi, Marıa Munoz-Amatriaın, Qihua Liang, Shengqiang Shu, Steve I. Wanamaker, Sassoum Lo, Jaakko Tanskanen, Alan H. Schulman, Tingting Zhu, Ming-Cheng Luo, Hind Alhakami, Rachid Ounit, Abid Md. Hasan, Jerome Verdier, Philip A. Roberts, Jansen R.P. Santos, Arsenio Ndeve, Jaroslav Dolezel, Jan Vrana, Samuel A. Hokin, Andrew D. Farmer, Steven B. Cannon,  Timothy J. Close. 2023. The genome of cowpea (Vigna unguiculata [L.] Walp.): Cowpea Chromosome Polynomial Formulae. Dataset. USAID Development Data Library. https://data.usaid.gov/d/xee6-zq8j.

Stefano Lonardi, Marıa Munoz-Amatriaın, Qihua Liang, Shengqiang Shu, Steve I. Wanamaker, Sassoum Lo, Jaakko Tanskanen, Alan H. Schulman, Tingting Zhu, Ming-Cheng Luo, Hind Alhakami, Rachid Ounit, Abid Md. Hasan, Jerome Verdier, Philip A. Roberts, Jansen R.P. Santos, Arsenio Ndeve, Jaroslav Dolezel, Jan Vrana, Samuel A. Hokin, Andrew D. Farmer, Steven B. Cannon,  Timothy J. Close
Bureau for Resilience and Food Security
There is no potentially sensitive data within this data asset.

The data and metadata that comprise this open access, peer-reviewed technical publication provide insight into the composition and architecture of the genome of cowpea via a high-quality, annotated genome sequence. The annotations include genes, repetitive sequences and positions of nearly one million genetic variants that exist within cultivated cowpeas. Relationships of the cowpea genome to common bean is highlighted, and each cowpea chromosome is mathematically described as recombination rate as a function of nucleotide position. This information provides a framework upon which to hang all past and future information about genetic variation within the species, as well as suites of genetic markers for any trait that has been or will be genetically mapped. Such information is useful for marker-assisted breeding, and to spawn basic research on mechanisms underlying the range of traits of cowpea.

resource.name: Feed the Future Malawi: Baseline Household Survey, Mothers File
resource.description: This dataset describes the mothers in the households that participated in this baseline survey.  The spreadsheet has 70 columns and 2,856 rows.  The Malawi Population-Based Survey (PBS) provides a comprehensive assessment of the current status of agriculture and food security in seven districts in the Central and Southern Regions: Mchinji, Lilongwe, Dedza, Ntcheu, Balaka, Machinga, and Mangochi.  The PBS was conducted from November 14 to December 22, 2012.  The overall objective of the survey is to provide baseline on data living standards, nutritional status, and women's empowerment in agriculture in the Zone Of Influence.  A total of 3,397 households in the ZOI were interviewed for the PBS, and these households were spread across 126 rural standard enumeration areas (SEAs) in the seven districts.

All GPS locations are rounded to 2 decimal places (accuracy of about 1 km) to protect sensitive sampling sites related to wildlife. Direct and indirect identifiers have been removed from human data using HIPAA Privacy Rule guidance and human data are aggregated and summarized to further protect individuals sampled.

This data includes both a wide range of variables and rare and unique variables related to known and novel viruses, including where and in what species they were found. Data were collected in Africa and Asia in communities with high-risk wildlife contact and includes variables that can inform on risk associated with zoonotic pathogen transmission and potential targets for intervention to minimize risk of pathogen spillover.

resource.name: FTF Ghana 2015 Interim Population-Based Survey: Decision-Making
resource.description: Feed the Future (FTF) initiative in Ghana is a collaborative effort that supports country-owned processes and plans for improving food security and nutrition, particularly in the northern part of the country. These datasets cover the interim survey that took place in 2015 and was designed as a follow-up to the baseline survey that happened from 2012 to 2013. The survey covered a range of indicators organized around four groups: (1) economic well-being; (2) women and children anthropometry; (3) hunger and diet diversity; and (4) women's empowerment. The survey design involved two stages in which enumeration areas were selected followed by households. Data was collected in a face-to-face fashion using well-designed questionnaires and other study materials.

domain_metadata.value: Kansas State University. 2019. FTF Ghana 2015 Interim Population-Based Survey: Decision-Making. Dataset. USAID Development Data Library. https://data.usaid.gov/d/xk6v-wvpk.

Data elements with no reported value have been removed. Data elements that provide the same information in terms of detail have been removed and the most balanced element of these data elements have been kept. Latitude and longitude structure of GPS have been removed. Data elements that carry no information value for research questions involving these data such as survey administration related data elements have been removed.
Data covers a wide range of indicators and variables that were included in the survey.

resource.name: Climate Change Impacts on Water Resources in Tanzania: Simulation Dataset
resource.description:
This dataset contains the hydrological simulation data reported in the article by Adhikari et al. (2016) found attached to the data asset.

Gridded daily historical climate data was constructed from Climate Research Unit (CRU) monthly data. Outputs from six climate models (CanESM2, CCSM4, CSIROMK3.6, IPSL-CM5A-LR, MPI-ESM-LR, and MRI-CGCM3) were used to construct the future climate scenarios. The whole country was divided into 17 watersheds based on the FAO watershed delineation. SWAT hydrological model was used to simulate the historical (1981-2000) as well as future (1941-2060) hydrological conditions.

The dataset has 57 variables and 895441 records. It contains the historical as well as future hydrological conditions under RCP 8.5 scenario projected by the six climate models (CanESM2, CCSM4, CSIROMK3.6, IPSL-CM5A-LR, MPI-ESM-LR, and MRI-CGCM3).

resource.name: Community Resilience Activity (CRA) Safe Charity Assessment: Phase 1 Indirect Farmers Data
resource.description:
The United States Agency for International Development (USAID)/Pakistan-funded Safe Charity campaign seeks to reduce financial support to violent extremist groups by educating those who give charity about how to direct their charity to safe recipients in Multan and Karachi. In Multan, the campaign trained influential farmers to disseminate safe charity messages to other farmers; and chambers of commerce and industry, trade and marketing associations, and the Rotary Club to reach the business community. In Karachi, the campaign engaged community youth centers to disseminate messages. The campaign timed its activities to align with common periods of charitable giving, namely Ramazan, Eid ul-Fitr, and Eid ul-Azha. 

These surveys established a baseline of current knowledge and practices with respect to safe charity in Multan and Karachi during each giving period and identified changes in knowledge and practices that could be plausibly linked to the safe charity campaign.

domain_tags: institute of social and policy sciences

domain_metadata.value: Management Systems International (MSI). 2020. Community Resilience Activity (CRA) Safe Charity Assessment: Phase 1 Indirect Farmers Data. Dataset. USAID Development Data Library. https://data.usaid.gov/d/xstq-w7gc.

The assessment conducted structured surveys of farmer and business communities in Multan and of participants of community youth center activities in Karachi. The assessment team collected survey data in two phases, each phase aligning with one of two selected periods of charitable and corresponding safe charity activities. Phase I aligned with activities relating to charitable giving during Ramazan and Eid ul-Fitr and collected data on decision-making patterns, knowledge, attitudes, and behavior with respect to the giving of zakat and fitrana during that period. Phase II aligned with activities relating to charitable giving during Eid ul-Azha and collected data on similar topics with respect to the giving of animal hides. The Phase II sample consisted primarily of individuals who had also participated in the Phase I survey. The primary limitation to the data from the Phase I survey was a snowball sampling approach to identifying survey respondents who had been exposed to safe charity messaging. For example, the survey team relied on farmer leaders, who had directly engaged with the safe charity campaign, to identify other members of farmer communities with knowledge of safe charity activities. While it was necessary to include “secondary” farmers in the survey sample to assess the reach of safe charity messaging within target communities, the survey team could not guarantee that secondary farmers had participated in safe charity activities or been exposed to safe charity messaging. Furthermore, there is a high likelihood of a selection bias in farmer leader referrals. To control for this bias, the survey team identified enough secondary farmers to create a secondary sampling frame, from which respondents could be randomly selected. The primary limitation to the survey of members of the business community was lack of familiarity with the safe charity campaign, particularly among corporate businesses. This may have been due to challenges identifying knowledgeable individuals within corporate businesses, lower levels of engagement between corporate businesses and their respective chambers of commerce, or characteristics of the corporate engagement strategy of the safe charity campaign.  Whereas the Phase I surveys focused on the giving of zakat and fitrana, the Phase II survey focused specifically on safe charity practices for the giving of qurbani. Phase II included only farmers and excluded the business community and Karachi youth center participants. The survey team employed a longitudinal design, surveying the same farmers who participated in Phase I. By surveying the same respondents, the assessment team examined layered (or repeated) exposure to safe charity activities and compared perceptions around different types of giving. However, given the unique circumstances and distinct forms of charity common to each charitable giving period, differences in behavior between Phase I and II should not be construed as change in behavior attributable to the safe charity campaign.

All unique individual identifiers, including names, addresses, and phone numbers of respondents, as well as names of data collection and processing teams, have been removed from the CRA Safe Charity study dataset and omitted from the final report. A unique identification code has been assigned to each survey respondent, reflecting the respondent’s geographic location (city), type of respondent (direct/indirect, farmers/businessman/workshop participants) and sex. The dataset does include information pertaining to respondents’ sex, educational attainment, religion, employment status, and income, which are important variables to explain variation in responses. These variables, however, together do not provide sufficient information to identify individual respondents.

The assessment team, led by MSI and the Institute of Social and Policy Sciences (I-SAPS), conducted structured surveys of farmer and business communities in Multan and of participants of community youth center activities in Karachi. The assessment team collected survey data in two phases, each phase aligning with one of two selected periods of charitable and corresponding safe charity activities. Phase I, which took place in August 2018, aligned with activities relating to charitable giving during Ramazan and Eid ul-Fitr and collected data on decision-making patterns, knowledge, attitudes, and behavior with respect to the giving of zakat and fitrana during that period. Phase II, which took place in October 2018, aligned with activities relating to charitable giving during Eid ul-Azha and collected data on similar topics with respect to the giving of animal hides. The Phase II sample consisted primarily of individuals who had also participated in the Phase I survey. Phase I included three surveys, each targeting a unique respondent group. In Multan, the assessment team selected a random sample of 124 farmer “leaders” from 500 farmers in 11 union councils who were directly engaged by the safe charity campaign. Farmer leaders were pre-identified influential members of their communities, tasked with disseminating information to other farmers and community members through community gatherings, sensitization sessions, and other activities and events. The sample of farmer leaders was stratified by gender and union council. With assistance from farmer leaders, the assessment team then used a snowball approach to identify a sampling frame of at least 500 “secondary” farmers, or members of target communities who participated in community gatherings, sensitizations sessions, and other activities and events sponsored by the safe charity campaign. Using this sampling frame, the assessment team selected a random sample of 150 secondary farmers, also stratified by gender and union council. The assessment team conducted a second Phase I survey of members of chambers of commerce and industry in Multan. The team randomly selected 150 businesses—120 members (40 corporate members and 80 associate members) of the Multan Chamber of Commerce and Industry (MCCI), whose total membership in Multan was approximately 1,000 businesses at the time of the survey; and 30 businesses from the Women Chamber of Commerce and Industry Multan (WCCIM), whose total membership in Multan was approximately 140 businesses at the time of the survey. The assessment team conducted a third Phase I survey of all 103 participants of safe charity poster workshops conducted at Azm-e-Naujawan (AeN) community youth centers. The campaign expected another 850 community members to attend AeN safe charity poster exhibits. Through AeN center staff and poster workshop participants, the assessment team used a snowball approach to identify a sampling frame of approximately 400 visitors to the poster exhibitions. From this sampling frame, the assessment team selected a random sample of 121 exhibit visitors, stratified by gender. As with secondary farmers, the snowball approach to identifying secondary participants could not ensure activity participation or exposure to safe charity messaging, and may have been subject to a selection bias. The Phase II survey focused solely on farmer leaders and secondary farmers in Multan. During Phase II, the assessment team surveyed 124 farmer leaders, 112 of whom were surveyed in Phase I and 12 of whom were new respondents who replaced farmers that could not be reached or who were unable to participate. Similarly, the assessment team surveyed 152 secondary farmers, 131 of whom were also surveyed in Phase 1, and 21 of whom were new respondents who replaced farmers that could not be reached or who were unable to participate. Together, these surveys provide a comprehensive snapshot of how people in these communities give charity and the role that the risk of giving to violent extremist groups plays in charitable decision-making. The surveys captured three types of information. First, they probed how people give charity, including frequency of giving, type of giving, who in the household makes charitable giving decisions, why people give charity, and factors determining to whom people give charity. Second, the surveys probed people’s knowledge of the risk of giving to violent extremist groups, where people obtain information about safe charity, and how this knowledge affects decision-making. Third, the surveys probed participation in safe charity activities and the effect of this participation on knowledge and behaviors, including further dissemination of safe charity messaging. The survey data can be disaggregated by gender, age, income, religion, and respondent type, as well as period of charitable giving. The two phases of data collection provide important insights into how hyperlocal conditions of place and time affect charitable decision-making and knowledge and practice of safe charity. The survey team employed a longitudinal design, surveying the same farmers who participated in Phase I. By surveying the same respondents, the assessment team examined layered (or repeated) exposure to safe charity activities and compared perceptions around different types of giving. However, given the unique circumstances and distinct forms of charity common to each charitable giving period, differences in behavior between Phase I and II should not be construed as change in behavior attributable to the safe charity campaign. The surveys are supplemented by in-depth individual and group interviews with primary and secondary safe charity participants.

resource.name: Feed the Future Tajikistan Zone of Influence Population Based Survey, Women's Empowerment in Agriculture Index-File 1
resource.description: The baseline survey in Tajikistan captures data in the Feed the Future Zones of Influence (ZOI), comprised of 12 of the 24 districts in Khatlon province. A total of 2,000 households in the ZOI were surveyed for the PBS data collection activity. These households are spread across 100 standard enumeration areas in the targeted districts. The survey is comprised of ten CSV files: a children's file, a household-level file, a household member level file, a women's file, several files describing consumption, and two files used to construct the Women's Empowerment in Agriculture Index. This dataset is the first of two datasets needed to calculate the WEAI-related measures. It contains Module G data from the primary adult (18+) female decisionmaker within each household (for the sub-sample of households with a primary adult female decisionmaker).

resource.name: Haiti Rice Sheath Blight 2018 - Bacteria Dataset
resource.description: This dataset captures bacteria data. This dataset contains 48 rows and 5 columns.  The research falls within the field of biological control of plant diseases. Bacteria isolated from rice plants had been screened for their antagonistic activity against Rhizoctonia solani (R. solani), the rice sheath disease pathogen. The data reported contain the inhibition zone resulting from the antagonistic interaction of the bacteria and R. solani. This experiment was performed by a USAID funded graduate student, Jhonson Leonard, in the laboratory of Dr. Jong Hyun Ham, located in the Department of Plant Pathology at the University of Louisiana.

domain_metadata.value: Dr. Jong Hyun Ham. 2021. Haiti Rice Sheath Blight 2018 - Bacteria Dataset. Dataset. USAID Development Data Library. https://data.usaid.gov/d/xy5y-ds9t.

This basic research data could be used to help individuals or organizations trying to find biological information about the rice sheath disease pathogen .  It looks at biological control approaches to disease control and the types of organisms associated with the rhizophere of rice plants with and without silica treatment.

resource.name: Testing Nudges to Increase Handwashing in Schools Among Pupils in the Philippines, 2019 Handwashing Observations Dataset
resource.description: In 2019-2020, IDinsight evaluated a handwashing “nudges” intervention in Zamboanga del Norte elementary schools.  The tested intervention consisted of the following nudges: painted footpath with spray-painted footprints from toilet stall to handwashing station, calendar of handwashing posters, “watching eye” sticker above the handwashing station, and arrow sticker pointing to a soap dish.  This data was collected through observations of  handwashing after toilet use.

resource.name: Section P2 Agricultural and Household Assets
resource.description: The survey interviewed 254 retailer shops in 10 sub-cities of Addis Ababa. 30 supermarkets, 20 mini-markets, 100 regular shops, 80 dairy shops and 24 open market shops selling dairy products were interviewed. Details of the sampling strategy is found in the attachment. The survey collected information on the characteristics of the shop, details of dairy products sold, prices and quality. Policy makers, research, and other stakeholders can use this data to analyses dairy value chain in Ethiopia and dairy retailing practices in Ethiopia. This data set was collected through research of the project “Improving the evidence and policies for better performing livestock systems in Ethiopia” lead by the International Food Policy Research Institution as part of the Feed the Future Innovation Lab for Livestock Systems.

resource.name: Baseline Study of Food for Peace Title II Development Food Assistance Program in Karamoja, Uganda--Sampling Weights
resource.description: This dataset describes the sampling scheme used in the Baseline Study of Food for Peace Title II Development Food Assistance Program in Karamoja, Uganda.  It has 34 columns and 4,766 rows.  In fiscal year 2012, USAID's Office of Food for Peace (FFP) awarded funding to private voluntary organizations (PVOs) to design and implement a multi-year Title II development food assistance program in Uganda.  The main purpose of the Title II program is to improve long-term food security of chronically food insecure population in the target regions.  FFP contracted a firm, ICF International to conduct a baseline study in targeted areas of the country prior to the start of the new program.  The purpose of the study was to assess the current status of key indicators, have a better understanding of prevailing conditions and perceptions of the population in the implementation areas, and serve as a point of comparison for future final evaluations.  Results would also be used to further refine program targeting and, where possible, to understand the relationship between variables to inform program design.  The study was conducted in 2013, while FFP expects to conduct final evaluations as close as possible to the end of the program five years later.  The data asset is comprised of six datasets: 1) a description of all members of the households surveyed, 2) data on maternal health and sanitation practices, 3) data about the children in the household, 4) data describing the agricultural practices of the household, 5) data describing the food consumption of the household (broken into 4 smaller spreadsheets), and 6) and a description of the weights that should be applied during the analysis of the other datasets.

resource.name: USAID Forward, Improved decision-making _2010-2016
resource.description: This dataset contains the number of completed high-quality evaluations in each USAID mission in the period 2010-2016, a part of the USAID Forward reform initiative that ran from 2010-2016.  USAID Forward improved the way that the Agency delivers foreign assistance by embracing new partnerships, investing in the catalytic role of innovation, and demanding a renewed focus on results.  In 2017, the Agency determined that the work advanced under USAID Forward had largely been institutionalized.  On this site, you will find the FY 2012-2016 data related to USAID Forward's three main areas of focus: 1) Deliver results on a meaningful scale through a strengthened USAID, 2) Promote sustainable development through high-impact partnerships and local solutions, and 3) Identify and scale up innovative, breakthrough solutions to intractable development challenges.  As of October 2017, we are no longer updating information, including collecting indicators, on this legacy effort.

resource.name: Feed the Future Tanzania Mboga na Matunda Private Sector Survey 2019 - Module J Production Costs
resource.description: This data asset contains data from the beneficiary based fiscal year 2019 annual results survey of private sector firms assisted by the Feed the Future Tanzania - Mboga na Matunda Project. The project works to improve the livelihoods of horticultural farmers in the regions of Iringa, Morogoro, Songwe, Mbeya, and Zanzibar, and strengthen the market system throughout the ZOI. The survey sample was developed using one level of stratification, firm type. Firms were selected from five different categories: Processor, Buyer, Local input supplier, Regional input supplier, Finance provider, and Other service provider. In total, 321 firms were surveyed. The data is split into modules. Module A captures basic identifying data on the firm. Module B captures information on the proprietors. Modules C, D, E, F, G and H capture data on sales of products and services. Module I captures information on business practices. Module J captures information on production costs. Module K captures information on access to finance.

Direct and indirect identifiers have been removed from human data using HIPAA Privacy Rule guidance and human data are aggregated and summarized to further protect individuals sampled.

This data includes both a wide range of variables and rare and unique variables related to known and novel viruses, including where and in what species they were found. Data were collected in Africa and Asia in communities with high-risk wildlife contact and includes variables that can inform on risk associated with zoonotic pathogen transmission and potential targets for intervention to minimize risk of pathogen spillover.

resource.name: Zambia Communications Support for Health Safe Love Campaign Outcome Evaluation
resource.description: The Safe Love campaign was a three-year comprehensive HIV prevention behavior change and communication (BCC) initiative implemented between June 2011 and June 2014.  The overall goal of the campaign was to contribute to the reduction of new HIV infections in Zambia by addressing key drivers of transmission, mainly low and inconsistent condom use, multiple concurrent partnerships, and low uptake of prevention of mother-to-child transmission services.  The campaign also included messages on uptake of voluntary medical male circumcision.

The Safe Love campaign was a three­yearcomprehensive HIV prevention behaviour change communication (BCC) initiativethat ran through June 2014.

resource.name: Comparison of four bacteriophages exposed to chlorine on stainless steel: summary data
resource.description:
The 2014 West African Ebola virus disease outbreak was the largest to date, and conflicting, chlorine-­based surface disinfection protocols to interrupt disease transmission were recommended. We identified only one study documenting surface disinfection efficacy against the Ebola virus, showing a >6.6 log reduction after 5­-minute exposure to 0.5% sodium hypochlorite (NaOCl) based on small­-scale tests (Cook et al. (2015)). In preparation for future extensive, large­-scale disinfection efficacy experiments, we replicated the Cook et al. experiment using four potential BSL­-1 surrogates selected based on similarities to the Ebola virus: bacteriophages MS2, M13, Phi6, and PR772. Each bacteriophage was exposed to 0.1% and 0.5% NaOCl for 1, 5, and 10 minutes on stainless steel. MS2 and M13 were only reduced by 3.4 log and 3.5 log after a 10-­minute exposure to 0.5% NaOCl, and would be overly conservative surrogates. Conversely, PR772 was too easily inactivated for surrogate use, as it was reduced by >4.8 log after only 1­-minute exposure to 0.5% NaOCl. Phi6 was slightly more resistant than the Ebola virus, with 4.1 log reduction after a 5­-minute exposure and not detected after a 10-­minute exposure to 0.5% NaOCl. We therefore recommend
Phi6 as a surrogate for evaluating the efficacy of chlorine-­based surface disinfectants against the Ebola virus.

resource.name: FtF Kenya Household Survey 2015: Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) Data
resource.description:
The Kenya Agricultural Value Chain Enterprises (KAVES) activity works with smallholder farmers, businesses, and national and county government partners to address constraints up and down the value chain (such as agro-processors, input suppliers, transporters, exporters, retailers, financiers) and develop fully-functioning, competitive value chains. KAVES aims to increase the productivity and incomes of smallholder farmers, and other actors along the value chain, who are working in the dairy, maize (and other staples), and horticulture sectors.

This data is derived from a 2015 survey collecting year-end results on activities related to crop production and sales, livestock production and sales, nutrition, water and sanitation, and access to financial services. Respondents are beneficiaries of the Kenya-­KAVES project.

We identified variables within the asset that present privacy risk (key variables) and applied a 3-anonymity technique on categorical key variables, such as county, sex and age group. In order to reach the 3-anonymity threshold, we recoded some variables and suppressed values that increased the risk of re-identification. Doing so reduces the precision of the cells, while preserving statistical utility. 3-anonymity mitigates risk on key categorical variables in a combined way.
Data were collected for a wide range of variables to better inform the design of the project and could potentially be reused to plan additional projects in the same sectors in other regions.

resource.name: Haiti Cover Crop Study Les Cayes 2018 - Eggplant Crop Weed Density Dataset
resource.description: This dataset captures weed density and weed fresh weight data during the eggplant season.  It contains 256 rows and 23 columns. This experiment looked at different cover crop performance grown in Les Cayes, Haiti and the subsequent crop of eggplant that was grown after the cover crop was incorporated into the soil.  This research was conducted by USAID funded graduate student, Jean Maude Louizias, under the supervision of Dr. Carlene Chase.

domain_metadata.value: Carlene Chase. 2023. Haiti Cover Crop Study Les Cayes 2018 - Eggplant Crop Weed Density Dataset. Dataset. USAID Development Data Library. https://data.usaid.gov/d/yesg-93kg.

This research lays the foundation for cover crop research in Haiti. It provides information on the growth, and weed suppression of cover crops and how specific cover crops effect on a crop of eggplant that follows the cover crop compared to not using cover crops.

resource.name: Data for Efficacy of Heavy Duty Tarp Disinfection (E. coli)
resource.description: In the 2014 West African Ebola outbreak, international organizations provided conflicting recommendations for disinfecting surfaces contaminated by uncontrolled patient spills. We compared the efficacy of four chlorine solutions (sodium hypochlorite, sodium dichloroisocyanurate, high ­test hypochlorite, and generated hypochlorite) for disinfection of three surface types (stainless steel, heavy duty tarp, and nitrile), with and without pre­cleaning practices (pre­wiping and/or covering) and soil load. The test organisms were E. coli and the Ebola surrogate Phi6. All tests achieved a minimum of 5.9­ and 3.1­log removal in E. coli and Phi6, respectively. A 15­-minute exposure to 0.5% chlorine was sufficient to ensure less than 8 Phi6 PFU/cm2 in all tests. While chlorine types were equally efficacious with and without soil load, variation was seen by surface type. Wiping did not increase disinfection efficacy, and is not recommended as it generates infectious waste. Covering spills decreased disinfection efficacy against E. coli on heavy ­duty tarp but does prevent splashing, which is critical in Ebola contexts. Our results support the recommendation of a 15-minute exposure to 0.5% chlorine, independently of chlorine type, surface, pre­-cleaning practices, and organic matter, as an efficacious measure to interrupt disease transmission from uncontrolled spills in Ebola outbreaks.

resource.name: Mekong Vitality Expanded (MVE) Assessment Data 2014
resource.description:
The Mekong Vitality Expanded (MVE) is transforming women from micro-enterprise operators to entrepreneurs who are business leaders, fully engaged in their communities. The project will enable women by equipping them with an understanding of sound business practices, market forces, and trade related opportunities. Facilitated by mobile technology, the program increases women’s access to key sources of market information and guides them to use that information to identify and seize more business opportunities.

Pact is augmenting the business development training for an estimated 300 of the 6,000 participants in its WORTH program. At the start of the project, Pact conducted a rapid assessment of barriers to women’s full engagement in business, adapted from the USAID Diagnostic of Women Entrepreneurs. The purpose of the assessment was to garner an in-depth understanding of the business environment as well as the capacity and needs of Vietnamese participants. Pact then developed an augmented business training curriculum based on the results of the startup assessment.

In order to introduce mobile technology for an e-learning application/platform of the business materials, the assessment integrated information about participants’ current level of capacity, the type of technology and devices currently most used by the women and their frequency of use. Members of existing WORTH groups will be given the opportunity to self-select into the MVE activities.

domain_metadata.value: Pact. 2019. Mekong Vitality Expanded (MVE) Assessment Data 2014. Dataset. USAID Development Data Library. https://data.usaid.gov/d/yhi6-5q4r.

This rapid assessment is under the USAID's Mekong Vitality Expanded project. This assessment collects information of the barriers to and needs regarding WORTH women’s engagement in business, as well as the participants’ current level of capacity and frequency of use of mobile technology and devices; in order to serve the project purposes.

resource.name: Transforming Education for Adults and Children in the Hinterlands Ethiopia 2013 Baseline EGRA
resource.description:
The Ethiopia TEACH II activity aimed to strengthen the provision of equitable basic education services by implementing alternative basic education for children and youth, functional literacy for adults and improving the capacity of Woreda Education Offices (WEO) to manage non-formal educational programs. The activity operated in eight regions and provided instruction in four languages. The target population of the study were Level II learners from selected woredas in the SNNP, Tigray, Amhara, Benishangul, Oromia, Afar, Gambella, and Somali regions where PACT-Ethiopia and its partners operated. Students were randomly selected to measure basic literacy skills targeted at the Grade 2 level using EGRA assessments in eight different languages. The EGRA assessment sub-tasks measuring basic literacy skills were incremental in their complexity. Each sub-task was presented to the child on a one–to-one basis. Questionnaires were also administered to understand the background of the students.

This data file contains the project's 2013 baseline EGRA.

The data files associated with this activity do not contain any personally identifiable information (PII) or school names but may contain individual student, teacher, head teacher, school codes, and other school level information that are recorded using unique identification variables. Each unique identification variable is de-identified by first creating a separate "masked" variable that retains the unique record but does not contain a meaningful value and then deleting the original unique identification variable for the data file. Please see the USAID Data Services DDL Variable Manipulation Overview,  https://data.usaid.gov/api/views/xw2i-z7hr/files/de8f1fd7-1803-43bf-9a5a-de5f67a57ccb, noting the risk mitigation techniques implemented in some data assets on the DDL, as well as examples of the impact of these techniques on the data.

resource.name: Ghana Early Grade Math Pilot Impact Evaluation: Endline Math Coach Dataset
resource.description: The Early Grade Math Pilot program in Ghana, implemented under the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) Partnership for Education Learning Activity, was evaluated with an independent randomized controlled trial between 2017 and 2018. This data asset contains the two waves of data collected in Ghana during this time period. This dataset contains survey math coach data from the activity endline.

domain_metadata.value: Social Impact. 2023. Ghana Early Grade Math Pilot Impact Evaluation: Endline Math Coach Dataset. Dataset. USAID Development Data Library. https://data.usaid.gov/d/yn4n-9iqu.

All data sets in this data asset have been comprehensively anonymized according to Social Impact procedures. Anonymization procedures included removing direct identifiers and removing or recoding indirect identifiers. These datasets were subsequently reviewed and approved for dissemination by Social Impact's internal Institutional Review Board.

This data asset contains detailed data from a total of four survey instruments, one classroom observation tool, and pupil scores on the EGRA and GENA assessments. This data was collected from 120 schools, 240 teachers, and 4,800 pupils. As such, this data asset contains substantial information regarding primary education in Ghana.

resource.name: Feed the Future Tajikistan Zone of Influence Population Based Survey, Durable Goods Expenditures
resource.description: The baseline survey in Tajikistan captures data in the Feed the Future Zones of Influence (ZOI), comprised of 12 of the 24 districts in Khatlon province. A total of 2,000 households in the ZOI were surveyed for the PBS data collection activity. These households are spread across 100 standard enumeration areas in the targeted districts. The survey is comprised of ten CSV files: a children's file, a household-level file, a household member level file, a women's file, several files describing consumption, and two files used to construct the Women's Empowerment in Agriculture Index. This dataset contains data from sub-Module E7: Durable Goods Expenditures.

resource.name: Haiti Cover Crop Study Les Cayes 2018 - Eggplant Shoot Biomass Dataset
resource.description: This dataset captures shoot biomass data collected after final harvest. It contains 64 rows and 12 columns. This experiment looked at different cover crop performance grown in Les Cayes, Haiti and the subsequent crop of eggplant that was grown after the cover crop was incorporated into the soil.  This research was conducted by USAID funded graduate student, Jean Maude Louizias, under the supervision of Dr. Carlene Chase.

domain_metadata.value: Carlene Chase. 2023. Haiti Cover Crop Study Les Cayes 2018 - Eggplant Shoot Biomass Dataset. Dataset. USAID Development Data Library. https://data.usaid.gov/d/ysc5-e8mm.
This data set evaluates eggplant shoot biomass following different cover crops and bare soil production in Les Cayes Haiti.

resource.name: Building Energy Performance Survey Data
resource.description:
One of the specific objectives of the USAID/Vietnam Clean Energy Program is to develop a comprehensive database of buildings in collaboration with the Departments of Constructions in five cities to identify almost all larger buildings (with Gross Floor Area [GFA] equal to or greater than 2,500 m2) that have been constructed during the last 10 years (building stock). The Building Stock Sample contains some 1,400 large buildings of all categories and representative of 3 typical climate zones:
• Northern zone (Hanoi & Hai Phong cities): 490 buildings
• Central zone (Danang city): 316 buildings
• Southern zone (Ho Chi Minh and Can Tho cities): 623 buildings

The stock data contains basic information for each building, including building type, year built, total floor area; many buildings contain extra information such as number of stories, number of lifts, type and size of electric generator, etc. For the detailed building energy performance survey, the Program’s approach is to randomly select 280 buildings (20%) from Departments of Construction sample stocks of buildings for a detailed survey. For the credibility of collected data, surveyed buildings must be statistically representative of each climate zone and building type/size category. For each climate zone, the optimal sample size will contain at least five buildings in each of the building categories. All data went through a third party quality assurance check.

resource.name: REVIVE Climate Change Adaptation in Oromia, Ethiopia: Baseline Dataset
resource.description:
The baseline dataset for this study contains 1439 observations over 156 variables. The data describe animal numbers with some socio-demographic information and some opinions.

These data come from the Restoring Vibrant Villages and Environments (REVIVE) project in 9 woredas of Oromia region of Ethiopia. Project REVIVE is a three­year project to increase vulnerable communities’ long­term resilience to climate change and climate­-related shocks.

domain_metadata.value: Jason Rubin. 2019. REVIVE Climate Change Adaptation in Oromia, Ethiopia: Baseline Dataset. Dataset. USAID Development Data Library. https://data.usaid.gov/d/yu79-vkkx.

The following data mitigation techniques were applied in order to preserve 3-anonymity and keep the risk ofre-identification to 7%1) Aggregating age groups (Age) (<=20, 21-30, 31-40, 41-50, 51-60, older than 60).2) Top-codingAnimals in good condition (Goats, Cattle, Sheet and Camels): 20 or more.Total animal counts (Cattle, Sheep, Camels and Goats): 20 or more.Animals died: (Cattle and goats): 20 or more.Animals sold: (Sheep and goats): 20 or more.Household size: Replaced values 13 or larger with 15.3) Local suppression (Woreda, Age, Sex and Livelihood)
The data support the three objectives in the description and also will aid in project post-evaluation.

resource.name: Agricultural Land Dynamics and Land Policy in Rural Tanzania 2016: Livestock Costs Dataset
resource.description:
This dataset contains information about costs associated with livestock inputs. The table can be combined with other datasets in this data asset using the 'hhid' column.

The purpose of collecting these data was to examine farm expansion and labor markets in rural Tanzania. Data were collected in 8 rural districts of Tanzania: Mvomero, Kilombero, Njombe, Kiteto, Magu, Moshi Rural, Mkuranga and Liwale.

The data were collected through the Feed the Future Innovation Lab for Food Security Policy (FSP).

domain_metadata.value: Margaret Beaver. 2019. Agricultural Land Dynamics and Land Policy in Rural Tanzania 2016: Livestock Costs Dataset. Dataset. USAID Development Data Library. https://data.usaid.gov/d/yv95-8ztk.
See the word document "2016_ALDSDataFileNotes.doc" for details on specific variables that may have data issues. Some plot areas were not allocated by crop but given as total area (see notes)

Examine the rate of land expansion of medium- and large-scale farms compared
to small scale farms, look at policy implications of consequent changes in
farm structure and the concentration of food production and marketed output;
Examine the pace of acquisition of agricultural land by medium- and
large-scale investors through de facto land administration policies; examine
the implication of such dynamics on rural youth land accessibility and out
migration in the context of customary tenure systems; assess the broader
effects of changing farm structure on the types of pace of non-farm
employment growth; understand the relationship between farm size and
efficiency, including the range of factors and policies that might condition
this relationship and specifically examine the impacts of large commercial
agricultural operations on the welfare of rural communities around them.
Examine the extent of land disputes and conflicts in rural Tanzania, their
causes, possible resolution mechanisms, and policy implications to land
investments in Tanzania as well as the implications of the formal and
informal land tenure systems in shaping incidence and intensity of land
dynamics.
